prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong in this situation.

So the setup is that the husband works from home a few days a week and set up his office in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion to use the basement. The wife is handling most of the housework and childcare, and when he's in the bedroom, she can't do anything without disturbing him. The husband is on calls most of the time, so the whole top floor is off-limits. The wife feels it's unfair because the basement is available and quiet, but he chose the bedroom for the view. She can't even take a shower or nap without worrying about disturbing him.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband might be prioritizing his work environment because he finds the view better, which could help his focus. But the wife is dealing with a lot of responsibilities and her ability to do her job and manage the household is being hindered. 

The key points here are communication and compromise. The wife suggested the basement as a better option for him, which would be quieter for his work. But he chose the bedroom. Now, she can't guarantee silence there, which affects her daily life. The husband is on conference calls, so he needs a quiet space, but he's in a shared living area (the bedroom). 

Is the wife obligated to keep that space undisturbed even though he didn't listen to her suggestion? Maybe not. If he had taken the basement, the problem wouldn't exist. By choosing the bedroom, he's placing himself in a space where the wife can't avoid using. The husband is the one who decided to set up there despite being told the basement is better. So the wife isn't at fault for not being able to keep the bedroom quiet when he's in a situation he chose himself. 

The husband's choice leads to the conflict. The wife is trying to balance her own work and household duties, which are essential. The husband might be in the wrong for not considering the impact of his decision on her. Therefore, the author is not in the wrong.
